subject: Ethics
title: Rules for Naval Warfare
description: A micro-lesson that makes Rules for Naval Warfare usable.

hook.text: A submarine spots an enemy merchant ship carrying food to a hostile port. Can it torpedo the ship?

buildup.text: Naval warfare rules require warning before attacking merchant vessels and rescuing survivors.

discovery.text: The 1936 London Naval Treaty demanded submarines surface and evacuate crews before sinking ships.

twist.text: In both World Wars, submarines ignored thisâ€”surfacing made them easy targets. The rule was suicidal.

climax.text: Admiral DÃ¶nitz was convicted at Nuremberg for unrestricted submarine warfare, then quietly pardoned.

punchline.text: Rules that get you killed tend to get ignored.

quiz.question: Why did submarines routinely violate the London Naval Treaty during World War II?
options: No nation had actually ratified the treaty before the war began
The treaty only applied to surface warships, not submarines
Surfacing to warn merchant ships made submarines vulnerable to attack
